He taught a prating Stare to speak my name;
And when he found a Nest of Nightingales,
Or callow Linnets, he would show 'em me,
And let me take 'em out.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: This is a little Mistris, meanly born,
Fit onely for a Prince his vacant hours,
And then, to laugh at her simplicity,
Not fix a passion there. Now hear my sentence.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Remember, ere you give it, 'tis pronounc'd
Against us both.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: First, in her hand
There shall be plac'd a Player's painted Sceptre,
And, on her head, a gilded Pageant Crown;
Thus shall she go,
With all the Boys attending on her Triumph:
That done, be put alone into a Boat,
With bread and water onely for three days,
So on the Sea she shall be set adrift,
And who relieves her, dies.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I onely beg that you would execute
The last part first: let me be put to Sea;
The bread and water, for my three days life,
I give you back, I would not live so long;
But let me scape the shame.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Look to me, Piety; and you, O Gods, look to my piety:
Keep me from saying that which misbecomes a son;
But let me die before I see this done.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: If you for ever will abjure her sight,
I can be yet a father; she shall live.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hear, O you Pow'rs, is this to be a father?
I see 'tis all my happiness and quiet
You aim at, Sir; and take 'em:
I will not save ev'n my Palmyra's life
At that ignoble price; but I'll die with her.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: So had I done by you,
Had Fate made me a Princess: Death, methinks,
Is not a terrour now;
He is not fierce, or grim, but fawns, and sooths me,
And slides along, like Cleopatra's Aspick,
Off'ring his service to my troubled breast.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Begin what you have purpos'd when you please,
Lead her to scorn, your triumph shall be doubled.
As holy Priests
In pity go with dying malefactours,
So will I share her shame.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: You shall not have your will so much; first part 'em,
Then execute your office.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — No; I'll die
In her defence. Draws his sword.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: — Ah, hold, and pull not on
A curse, to make me worthy of my death:
Do not by lawless force oppose your Father,
Whom you have too much disobey'd for me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Here, take it, Sir, and with it, pierce my heart:
sp.stage: Presenting his sword to his father upon his knees.
sp.l: You have done more, in taking my Palmyra.
You are my Father, therefore I submit.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Keep him from any thing he may design
Against his life, whil'st the first fury lasts;
And now perform what I commanded you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In vain; if sword and poison be deni'd me,
I'll hold my breath and die.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Farewell, my last Leonidas; yet live,
I charge you live, till you believe me dead.
I cannot die in peace, if you die first.
If life's a blessing, you shall have it last.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Go on with her, and lead him after me.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: I bring you, Sir, such news as must amaze you,
And such as will prevent you from an action
Which would have rendred all your life unhappy.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Hermogenes, you bend your knees in vain,
My doom's already past.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I kneel not for Palmyra, for I know
She will not need my pray'rs; but for my self:
With a feign'd tale I have abus'd your ears,
And therefore merit death; but since, unforc'd,
I first accuse my self, I hope your mercy.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Haste to explain your meaning.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then, in few words, Palmyra is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: How can I give belief to this Impostor?
He who has once abus'd me, often may.
I'l hear no more.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: — For your own sake, you must.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: A parent's love (for I confess my crime)
Mov'd me to say, Leonidas was yours;
But when I heard Palmyra was to die,
The fear of guiltless bloud so stung my conscience,
That I resolv'd, ev'n with my shame, to save
Your daughter's life.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: But how can I be certain, but that interest,
Which mov'd you first to say your son was mine,
Does not now move you too, to save your daughter?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You had but then my word; I bring you now
Authentick testimonies. Sir, in short,
sp.stage: Delivers on his knees a Iewel, and a Letter.
sp.l: If this will not convince you, let me suffer.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: I know this Jewel well; 'twas once my mothers,
Which, marrying, I presented to my wife.
And this, O this, is my Eudocia's hand.
This was the pledge of love given to Eudocia, Reads:
Who, dying, to her young Palmyra leaves it:
And this when you, my dearest Lord, receive,
Own her, and think on me, dying Eudocia.
Take it; 'tis well there is no more to read, To Argaleon.
My eyes grow full, and swim in their own light.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I fear, Sir, this is your intended Pageant.
You sport your self at poor Palmyra's cost;
But if you think to make me proud,
Indeed I cannot be so: I was born
With humble thoughts, and lowly, like my birth.
A real fortune could not make me haughty,
Much less a feign'd.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: — This was her mother's temper.
I have too much deserv'd thou shouldst suspect
That I am not thy father; but my love
Shall henceforth show I am. Behold my eyes,
And see a father there begin to flow:
This is not feign'd, Palmyra.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I doubt no longer, Sir; you are a King,
And cannot lie: falshood's a vice too base
To find a room in any Royal breast;
I know, in spight of my unworthiness,
I am your child; for when you would have kill'd me,
Methought I lov'd you then.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Sir, we forget the Prince Leonidas,
His greatness should not stand neglected thus.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Guards, you may now retire: Give him his sword,
And leave him free.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Then the first use I make of liberty
Shall be, with your permission, mighty Sir,
To pay that reverence to which Nature binds me.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Sure you forget your birth thus to misplace
This act of your obedience; you should kneel
To nothing but to Heav'n, and to a King.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I never shall forget what Nature owes,
Nor be asham'd to pay it; though my father
Be not a King, I know him brave and honest,
And well deserving of a worthier son.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: He bears it gallantly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Why would you not instruct me, Sir, before To Herm.
Where I should place my duty?
From which, if ignorance have made me swerve,
I beg your pardon for an erring son.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I almost grieve I am a Princess, since
It makes him lose a Crown.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And next, to you, my King, thus low I kneel,
T' implore your mercy; if in that small time
I had the honour to be thought your son,
I pay'd not strict obedience to your will:
I thought, indeed, I should not be compell'd,
But thought it as your son; so what I took
In duty from you, I restor'd in courage;
Because your son should not be forc'd.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: You have my pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: To you, fair Princess, I congratulate
Your birth; of which I ever thought you worthy:
And give me leave to add, that I am proud
The Gods have pick'd me out to be the man
By whose dejected fate yours is to rise;
Because no man could more desire your fortune,
Or franklier part with his to make you great.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I know the King, though you are not his son,
Will still regard you as my Foster-brother,
And so conduct you downward from a Throne,
By slow degrees, so unperceiv'd and soft,
That it may seem no fall: or, if it be,
May Fortune lay a bed of down beneath you.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: He shall be rank'd with my Nobility,
And kept from scorn by a large pension giv'n him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You are all great and Royal in your gifts; Bowing.
But at the Donor's feet I lay 'em down:
Should I take riches from you, it would seem
As I did want a soul to bear that poverty
To which the Gods design'd my humble birth:
And should I take your Honours without merit,
It would appear, I wanted manly courage
To hope 'em, in your service, from my sword.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Still brave, and like your self.
The Court shall shine this night in its full splendor,
And celebrate this new discovery.
Argaleon, lead my daughter: as we go
I shall have time to give her my commands,
In which you are concern'd. Exeunt all but Leonidas.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Methinks I do not want
That huge long train of fawning followers,
That swept a furlong after me.
'Tis true, I am alone;
So was the Godhead ere he made the world,
And better serv'd Himself, then serv'd by Nature.
And yet I have a Soul
Above this humble fate. I could command,
Love to do good; give largely to true merit;
All that a King should do: But though these are not
My Province, I have Scene enough within
To exercise my vertue.
All that a heart, so fix'd as mine, can move,
Is, that my niggard fortune starves my love. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Palamede and Doralice meet: she with a Book in her hand, seems to start at sight of him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'TIs a strange thing that no warning will serve your turn; and that no retirement will secure me from your impertinent addresses! Did not I tell you, that I was to be private here at my devotions?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Yes; and you see I have observ'd my Cue exactly: I am come to releive you from them. Come, shut up, shut up your Book; the man's come who is to supply all your necessities.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then, it seems, you are so impudent to think it was an assignation? this, I warrant, was your lewd interpretation of my innocent meaning.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Venus forbid that I should harbour so unreasonable a thought of a fair young Lady, that you should lead me hither into temptation. I confess I might think indeed it was a kind of honourable challenge, to meet privately without Seconds, and decide the difference betwixt the two Sexes; but heaven forgive me if I thought amiss.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You thought too, I'll lay my life on't, that you might as well make love to me, as my Husband does to your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I was so unreasonable to think so too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And then you wickedly inferr'd, that there was some justice in the revenge of it: or at least but little injury; for a man to endeavour to enjoy that, which he accounts a blessing, and which is not valu'd as it ought by the dull possessour. Confess your wickedness, did you not think so?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I confess I was thinking so, as fast as I could; but you think so much before me, that you will let me think nothing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis the very thing that I design'd: I have forestall'd all your arguments, and left you without a word more, to plead for mercy. If you have any thing farther to offer, ere Sentence pass— Poor Animal, I brought you hither onely for my diversion.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: That you may have, if you'll make use of me the right way; but I tell thee, woman, I am now past talking.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But it may be, I came hither to hear what fine things you could say for your self.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: You would be very angry, to my knowledge, if I should lose so much time to say many of 'em— By this hand you would—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fie, Palamede, I am a woman of honour.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I see you are; you have kept touch with your assignation: and before we part, you shall find that I am a man of honour— yet I have one scruple of conscience—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I warrant you will not want some naughty argument or other to satisfie your self— I hope you are afraid of betraying your friend?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Of betraying my friend! I am more afraid of being betray'd by you to my friend. You women now are got into the way of telling first your selves: a man who has any care of his reputation will be loath to trust it with you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O you charge your faults upon our Sex: you men are like Cocks, you never make love, but you clap your wings, and crow when you have done.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Nay, rather you women are like Hens; you never lay, but you cackle an hour after, to discover your Nest— But I'll venture it for once.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To convince you that you are in the wrong, I'll retire into the dark Grotto, to my devotion, and make so little noise, that it shall be impossible for you to find me.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: But if I find you—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, if you find me— But I'll put you to search in more corners then you imagine.

div.stage: She runs in, and he after her.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let me die, but this solitude, and that Grotto are scandalous; I'll go no further; besides, you have a sweet Lady of your own.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But a sweet Mistris, now and then, makes my sweet Lady so much more sweet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I hope you will not force me?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But I will, if you desire it.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: (Within) Where the devil are you, Madam? S'death, I begin to be weary of this hide and seek: if you stay a little longer, till the fit's over, I'll hide in my turn, and put you to the finding me. He enters, and sees Rhodophil and Melantha. How! Rhodophil and my Mistris!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: My servant to apprehend me! this is Surprenant au dernièr.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I must on; there's nothing but impudence can help me out.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Rhodophil, How came you hither in so good company?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: As you see, Palamede; an effect of pure friendship; I was not able to live without you.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: But what makes my Mistris with you?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Why, I heard you were here alone, and could not in civility but bring her to you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You'll pardon the effects of a passion which I may now avow for you, if it transported me beyond the rules of bien seance.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: But who told you I was here? they that told you that, may tell you more, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: O, for that matter, we had intelligence.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: But let me tell you, we came hither so very privately, that you could not trace us.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Us? what us? you are alone.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Us! the devil's in me for mistaking: me, I meant. Or us; that is, you are me, or I you, as we are friends: that's us.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Palamede, Palamede. Within.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I should know that voice? who's within there, that calls you?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Faith I can't imagine; I believe the place is haunted.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Palamede, Palamede, All-cocks hidden. Within.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Lord, lord, what shall I do? Well, dear friend, to let you see I scorn to be jealous, and that I dare trust my Mistris with you, take her back, for I would not willingly have her frighted, and I am resolv'd to see who's there; I'll not be danted with a Bug-bear, that's certain: prethee dispute it not, it shall be so; nay, do not put me to swear, but go quickly: there's an effect of pure friendship for you now.

div.stage: Enter Doralice, and looks amaz'd, seeing them.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Doralice! I am thunder-struck to see you here.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: So am I! quite thunder-struck. Was it you that call'd me within? (I must be impudent.)

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: How came you hither, Spouse?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Ay, how came you hither? And, which is more, how could you be here without my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
(To her husband) O, Gentleman, have I caught you i'faith!
have I broke forth in ambush upon you! I thought my suspicions would prove true.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Suspicions! this is very fine, Spouse!
Prethee what suspicions?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O, you feign ignorance: why, of you and Melantha; here have I staid these two hours, waiting with all the rage of a passionate, loving wife, but infinitely jealous, to take you two in the manner; for hither I was certain you would come.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But you are mistaken, Spouse, in the occasion; for we came hither on purpose to find Palamede, on intelligence he was gone before.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd then if the same party who gave you intelligence, I was here, did not tell your wife you would come hither: now I smell the malice on't on both sides.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Was it so, think you? nay, then, I'll confess my part of the malice too. As soon as ever I spi'd my husband and Melantha come together, I had a strange temptation to make him jealous in revenge; and that made me call Palamede, Palamede, as though there had been an Intrigue between us.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Nay, I avow, there was an apparence of an Intrigue between us too.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: To see how things will come about!

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: And was it onely thus, my dear Doralice? Embraces.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And did I wrong none, Rhodophil, with a false suspicion? Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p:
(Aside) Now am I confident we had all four the same design: 'tis a pretty odd kind of game this, where each of us plays for double stakes: this is just thrust and parry with the same motion; I am to get his Wife, and yet to guard my own Mistris. But I am vilely suspitious, that, while I conquer in the Right Wing, I shall be routed in the Left: for both our women will certainly betray their party, because they are each of them for gaining of two, as well as we; and I much fear,
If their necessities and ours were known,
They have more need of two, then we of one.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Leonidas, musing, Amalthea following him.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: YOnder he is, and I must speak, or die;
And yet 'tis death to speak; yet he must know
I have a passion for him, and may know it
With a less blush; because to offer it
To his low fortunes, shows I lov'd before,
His person, not his greatness.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: First scorn'd, and now commanded from the Court!
The King is good; but he is wrought to this
By proud Argaleon's malice.
What more disgrace can Love and Fortune joyn
T' inflict upon one man? I cannot now
Behold my dear Palmyra: she, perhaps, too
Is grown asham'd of a mean ill-plac'd love.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Assist me, Venus, for I tremble when Aside.
I am to speak, but I must force my self.
Sir, I would crave but one short minute with you, To him.
And some few words.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — The proud Argaleon's sister! Aside.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Alas, it will not out; shame stops my mouth. Aside.
Pardon my errour, Sir, I was mistaken,
And took you for another.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: In spight of all his guards, I'll see Palmyra; Aside.
Though meanly born, I have a Kingly Soul yet.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: I stand upon a precipice, where fain Aside.
I would retire, but Love still thrusts me on:
Now I grow bolder, and will speak to him.
Sir, 'tis indeed to you that I would speak, To him.
And if—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O, you are sent to scorn my fortunes;
Your Sex and Beauty are your priviledge;
But should your Brother—

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Now he looks angry, and I dare not speak.
I had some business with you, Sir,
But 'tis not worth your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Then 'twill be charity to let me mourn
My griefs alone, for I am much disorder'd.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: 'Twill be more charity to mourn 'em with you:
Heav'n knows I pity you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Your pity, Madam,
Is generous, but 'tis unavailable.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: You know not till 'tis tri'd.
Your sorrows are no secret; you have lost
A Crown, and Mistris.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Are not these enough?
Hang two such weights on any other soul,
And see if it can bear 'em.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: More; you are banish'd, by my Brother's means,
And ne'r must hope again to see your Princess;
Except as Pris'ners view fair Walks and Streets,
And careless Passengers going by their grates,
To make 'em feel the want of liberty.
But, worse then all,
The King this morning has injoyn'd his Daughter
T' accept my Brother's love.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Is this your pity?
You aggravate my griefs, and print 'em deeper
In new and heavier stamps.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: 'Tis as Physicians show the desperate ill
T' indear their Art, by mittigating pains
They cannot wholly cure: when you despair
Of all you wish, some part of it, because
Unhop'd for, may be grateful; and some other—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What other?

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Some other may—
My shame again has seiz'd me, and I can go Aside.
No farther—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: These often failing, sighs, and interruptions,
Make me imagine you have grief like mine:
Have you ne'r lov'd?

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: — I? never: 'tis in vain;
I must despair in silence. Aside.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You come as I suspected then, to mock,
At least observe my griefs: take it not ill
That I must leave you. Is going.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: You must not go with these unjust opinions.
Command my life, and fortunes; you are wise,
Think, and think well, what I can do to serve you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I have but one thing in my thoughts and wishes:
If by your means I can obtain the sight
Of my ador'd Palmyra; or, what's harder,
One minutes time, to tell her, I die hers. She starts back.
I see I am not to expect it from you;
Nor could, indeed, with reason.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Name any other thing: is Amalthea
So despicable, she can serve your wishes
In this alone?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — If I should ask of heav'n,
I have no other suit.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: To show you, then, I can deny you nothing,
Though 'tis more hard to me then any other,
Yet I will do't for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Name quickly, name the means, speak my good Angel.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Be not so much o'rjoy'd; for, if you are,
I'll rather dye then do't. This night the Court
Will be in Masquerade;
You shall attend on me; in that disguise
You may both see and speak to her,
If you dare venture it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yes, were a God her Guardian,
And bore in each hand thunder. I would venture.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Farewell then; two hours hence I will expect you:
My heart's so full, that I can stay no longer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Already it grows dusky; I'll prepare
With haste for my disguise. But who are these?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: 'Tis he; we need not fear to speak to him.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Leonidas.

sp.speaker: Leonidas.
sp.l: — Sure I have known that voice.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You have some reason, Sir; 'tis Eubulus,
Who bred you with the Princess; and, departing,
Bequeath'd you to my care.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Foster, Father! let my knees express Kneeling.
My joys for your return!

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Rise, Sir, you must not kneel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — E'r since you left me,
I have been wandring in a maze of fate,
Led by false fires of a fantastick glory,
And the vain lustre of imagin'd Crowns,
But, ah! why would you leave me? or how could you
Absent yourself so long?

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: I'll give you a most just account of both:
And something more I have to tell you, which
I know must cause your wonder; but this place,
Though almost hid in darkness, is not safe.
Already I discern some coming towards us Torches appear.
With lights, who may discover me. Hermogenes,
Your lodgings are hard by, and much more private.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: There you may freely speak.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Let us make haste;
For some affairs, and of no small importance,
Call me another way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Palamede and Rhodophil, with Vizor Masques in their hands, and Torches before 'em.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: We shall have noble sport to night, Rhodophil; this Masquerading is a most glorious invention.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I believe it was invented first by some jealous Lover, to discover the haunts of his Jilting Mistris; or, perhaps, by some distressed servant, to gain an opportunity with a jealous man's wife.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: No, it must be the invention of a woman, it has so much of subtilty and love in it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I am sure 'tis extremely pleasant; for to go unknown, is the next degree to going invisible.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: What with our antique habits, and feign'd voices, do you know me? and I know you? Methinks we move and talk just like so many over-grown Puppets.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Masquerade is onely Vizor-masque improv'd, a heightning of the same fashion.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: No; Masquerade is Vizor-masque in debauch; and I like it the better for't: for, with a Vizor-masque, we fool our selves into courtship, for the sake of an eye that glanc'd; or a hand that stole it self out of the glove sometimes, to give us a sample of the skin: but in Masquerade there is nothing to be known, she's all Terra incognita, and the bold discoverer leaps ashoar, and takes his lot among the wild Indians and Salvages, without the vile consideration of safety to his person, or of beauty, or wholesomeness in his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Beliza, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady sent me after you, to let you know, she finds her self a little indispos'd, so that she cannot be at Court, but is retir'd to rest, in her own appartment, where she shall want the happiness of your dear embraces to night.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: A very fine phrase, Beliza, to let me know my wife desires to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I doubt, Rhodophil, you take the pains sometimes to instruct your wife's Woman in these elegancies.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Tell my dear Lady, that since I must be so unhappy as not to wait on her to night, I will lament bitterly for her absence. 'Tis true, I shall be at Court, but I will take no divertisement there; and when I return to my solitary bed, if I am so forgetful of my passion as to sleep, I will dream of her; and betwixt sleep and waking, put out my foot towards her side, for mid-night consolation; and not finding her, I will sigh, andimagine my self a most desolate widower.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shall do your commands, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: (Aside) She's sick as aptly for my purpose, as if she had contriv'd it so: well, if ever woman was a help-meet for man, my Spouse is so; for within this hour I receiv'd a Note from Melantha, that she would meet me this evening in Masquerade in Boys habit, to rejoyce with me before she entred into fetters; for I find she loves me better then Palamede, onely because he's to be her husband. There's something of antipathy in the word Marriage to the nature of love; marriage is the meer Ladle of affection, that cools it when 'tis never so fiercely boiling over.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Dear Rhodophil, I must needs beg your pardon; there is an occasion fall'n out which I had forgot: I cannot be at Court to night.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Dear Palamede, I am sorry we shall not have one course together at the herd; but I find your Game lies single: good fortune to you with your Mistris. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: He has wish'd me good fortune with his Wife: there's no sin in this then, there's fair leave given. Well, I must go visit the sick; I cannot resist the temptations of my charity. O what a difference will she find betwixt a dull resty Husband, and a quick vigorous Lover! he sets out like a Carrier's Horse, plodding on, because he knows he must, with the Bells of Matrimony chiming so melancholly about his neck, in pain till he's at his journeys end, and dispairing to get thither, he is fain to fortifie imagination with the thoughts of another woman: I, take heat after heat, like a well-breath'd Courser, and— But hark, what noise is that? swords! Clashing of Swords within.
Nay, then have with you. Exit Palamede.

div.stage: Re-enter Palamede, with Rhodophil: and Doralice in man's habit.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Friend, your relief was very timely, otherwise I had been oppress'd.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: What was the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: What I did, was in rescue of this Youth.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: What cause could he give 'em?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
The cause was nothing but onely the common cause
of fighting in Masquerades: they were drunk, and I was sober.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Have they not hurt you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No; but I am exceeding ill, with the fright on't.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Let's lead him to some place where he may refresh himself.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Do you conduct him then.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: (Aside) How cross this happens to my design of going to Doralice! for I am confident she was sick on purpose that I should visit her. Hark you, Rhodophil, could not you take care of the stripling? I am partly engag'd to night.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: You know I have business: but come, Youth, if it must be so.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: (To Rhodophil) No, good Sir, do not give your self that trouble; I shall be safer, and better pleas'd with your friend here.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Farewell then; once more I wish you a good adventure.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Damn this kindness! now must I be troubled with this young Rogue, and miss my opportunity with Doralice.

div.stage: Exit Rhodophil alone, Palamede with Doralice.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.l: Argaleon counsel'd well to banish him,
He has, I know not what,
Of greatness in his looks, and of high fate,
That almost awes me; but I fear my Daughter,
Who hourly moves me for him, and I mark'd
She sigh'd when I but nam'd Argaleon to her.
But see, the Maskers: hence my cares, this night,
At least take truce, and find me on my pillow.
div.stage: Enter the Princess in Masquerade, with Ladies: at the other end, Argaleon and Gentlemen in Masquerade: then Leonidas leading Amalthea. The King sits. A Dance. After the Dance,

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: (To Leonidas) That's the Princess;
I saw the habit ere she put it on.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I know her by a thousand other signs,
She cannot hide so much Divinity.
Disguis'd, and silent, yet some graceful motion
Breaks from her, and shines round her like a Glory.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Thus she reveals her self, and knows it not:
Like Love's Dark-lantern I direct his steps,
And yet he sees not that which gives him light.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I know you; but, alas, Leonidas, To Leonidas.
Why should you tempt this danger on your self?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Madam, you know me not, if you believe
I would not hazard greater for your sake:
But you, I fear, are chang'd.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: No, I am still the same;
But there are many things became Palmyra
Which ill become the Princess.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — I ask nothing
Which Honour will not give you leave to grant:
One hours short audience, at my fathers house,
You cannot sure refuse me.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Perhaps I should, did I consult strict vertue;
But something must be given to Love and you.
When would you I should come?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: This evening, with the speediest opportunity.
I have a secret to discover to you,
Which will surprise, and please you.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: — 'Tis enough.
Go now; for we may be observ'd and known.
I trust your honour; give me not occasion
To blame my self, or you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You never shall repent your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: I cannot be deceiv'd; that is the Princess:
One of her Maids betray'd the habit to me;
But who was he with whom she held discourse?
'Tis one she favours, for he kiss'd her hand.
Our shapes are like, our habits near the same:
She may mistake, and speak to me for him.
I am resolv'd, I'll satisfie my doubts,
Though to be more tormented. Exit.

lg.l: WHil'st Alexis lay prest
In her Arms he lov'd best,
With his hands round her neck,
And his head on her breast,
He found the fierce pleasure too hasty to stay,
And his soul in the tempest just flying away.
When Coelia saw this,
With a sigh, and a kiss,
She cry'd, Oh my dear, I am robb'd of my bliss;
'Tis unkind to your Love, and unfaithfully done,
To leave me behind you, and die all alone.
The Youth, though in haste,
And breathing his last,
In pity dy'd slowly, while she dy'd more fast;
Till at length she cry'd, Now, my dear, now let us go,
Now die, my Alexis, and I will die too.
Thus intranc'd they did lie,
Till Alexis did try
To recover new breath, that again he might die:
Then often they di'd; but the more they did so,
The Nymph di'd more quick, and the Shepherd more slow.

div.stage: Another Dance. After it, Argaleon re-enters, and stands by the Princess.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Leonidas, what means this quick return? To Arga.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: O heav'n! 'tis what I fear'd.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Is ought of moment happen'd since you went?

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: No, Madam, but I understood not fully
Your last commands.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: — And yet you answer'd to 'em.
Retire; you are too indiscreet a Lover:
I'll meet you where I promis'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: O my curst fortune! what have I discover'd?
But I will be reveng'd. Whispers to the King.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: But are you certain you are not deceiv'd?

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Upon my life.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: — Her honour is concern'd.
Somewhat I'll do; but I am yet distracted,
And know not where to fix. I wish'd a child,
And Heav'n, in anger, granted my request.
So blind we are, our wishes are so vain,
That what we most desire, proves most our pain.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: An Eating-house. Bottles of Wine on the Table. Palamede; and Doralice in Man's habit.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.p: (Aside) Now cannot I find in my heart to discover my self, though I long he should know me.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I tell thee, Boy, now I have seen thee safe, I must be gone: I have no leisure to throw away on thy raw conversation: I am a person that understand better things, I.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Were I a woman, Oh how you'd admire me! cry up every word I said, and scrue your face into a submissive smile; as I have seen a dull Gallant act Wit, and counterfeit pleasantness, when he whispers to a great Person in a Play-house; smile, and look briskly, when the other answers, as if something of extraordinary had past betwixt 'em, when, heaven knows, there was nothing else but, What a clock does your Lordship think it is? and my Lord's repertee is, 'Tis almost Park-time: or, at most, Shall we out of the Pit, and go behind the Scenes for an Act or two? And yet such fine things as these, would be wit in a Mistris's mouth.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Ay, Boy; there's Dame Nature in the case: he who cannot find wit in a Mistris, deserves to find nothing else, Boy. But these are riddles to thee, child, and I have not leisure to instruct thee; I have affairs to dispatch, great affairs; I am a man of business.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Come, you shall not go: you have no affairs but what you may dispatch here, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I find now, thou art a Boy of more understanding then I thought thee; a very lewd wicked Boy: o' my conscience thou wouldst debauch me, and hast some evil designs upon my person.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
You are mistaken, Sir; I would onely have you show me a more lawful reason why you would leave me, then I can why you should not, and I'll not stay you; for I am not so young, but I understand the necessities of flesh and bloud,
and the pressing occasions of mankind, as well as you.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: A very forward and understanding Boy! Thou art in great danger of a Pages wit, to be brisk at 14, and dull at 20. But I'll give thee no further account; I must, and will go.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My life on't, your Mistris is not at home.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: This Imp will make me very angry. I tell thee, young Sir, she is at home; and at home for me; and, which is more, she is abed for me, and sick for me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For you onely?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Ay, for me onely.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But how do you know she's sick abed?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: She sent her Husband word so.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And are you such a novice in Love, to believe a Wife's message to her Husband?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Why, what the devil should be her meaning else?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: It may be, to go in Masquerade as well as you; to observe your haunts, and keep you company without your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Nay, I'll trust her for that: she loves me too well, to disguise her self from me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I were she, I would disguise on purpose to try your wit; and come to my servant like a Riddle, Read me, and take me.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: I could know her in any shape: my good Genius would prompt me to find out a handsome woman: there's something in her, that would attract me to her without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then you make a Load-stone of your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Yes, and I carry Steel about me, which has been so often touch'd, that it never fails to point to the North Pole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yet still my mind gives me that you have met her disguis'd to night, and have not known her.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: This is the most pragmatical conceited little fellow, he will needs understand my business better then my self. I tell thee, once more, thou dost not know my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And I tell you, once more, that I know her better then you do.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p:
The Boy's resolv'd to have the last word,
I find I must go without reply. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ah mischief, I have lost him with my fooling. Palamede, Palamede.

div.stage: He returns. She plucks off her Perruke, and puts it on again when he knows her.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: O Heavens! is it you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Now, where was your good Genius, that would prompt you to find me out?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Why, you see I was not deceiv'd; you, your self, were my good Genius.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But where was the Steel, that knew the Load-stone? ha?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: The truth is, Madam, the Steel has lost its vertue; and therefore, if you please, we'll new touch it.

div.stage: Enter Rhodophil; and Melantha in Boy's habit. Rhodophil sees Palamede kissing Doralice 's hand.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Palamede again! am I fall'n into your quarters? What? ingaging with a Boy? is all honourable?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: O, very honourable on my side. I was just chastising this young Villain; he was running away, without paying his share of the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Then I find I was deceiv'd in him.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Yes, you are deceiv'd in him: 'tis the archest rogue, if you did but know him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good Rhodophil, let us get off al-a derobbée, for fear I should be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: There's no retiring now; I warrant you for discovery: now have I the oddest thought, to entertain you before your Servants face, and he never the wiser; 'twill be the prettiest jugling trick to cheat him when he looks upon us.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This is the strangest caprice in you.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: (To Doralice) This Rhodophil's the unluckiest fellow to me! this is now the second time he has bar'd the Dice when we were just ready to have nick'd him; but if ever I get the Box again—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Do you think he will not know me?
Am I like my self?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: No more then a Picture in the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay, then he can never discover me, now the wrong side of the Arras is turn'd towards him.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: At least, 'twill be some pleasure to me, to enjoy what freedom I can while he looks on; I will storm the Out-works of Matrimony even before his face.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: What Wine have you there, Palamede?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Old Chios, or the rogue's damn'd that drew it.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Come, to the most constant of Mistresses, that I believe is yours, Palamede.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray spare your Seconds; for my part I am but a weak Brother.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Now, to the truest of Turtles; that is your Wife, Rhodophil, that lies sick at home in the bed of honour.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Now let's have one common health, and so have done.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Then, for once, I'll begin it. Here's to him that has the fairest Lady of Sicily in Masquerade to night.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: This is such an obliging health, I'll kiss thee, dear Rogue, for thy invention Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: He who has this Lady, is a happy man, without dispute.— I'm most concern'd in this, I am sure. Aside.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Was it not well found out, Rhodophil?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ay, this was bien trouvée indeed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: (To Melantha.) I suppose I shall do you a kindness to enquire if you have not been in France, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To do you service, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O, Monsieur, vot valet bien humble. Saluting her.

p.hi: Votrè esclaue, Monsieur, de tout Mon Coeur.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I suppose, sweet Sir, you are the hope and joy of some thriving Citizen, who has pinch'd himself at home, to breed you abroad, where you have learnt your Exercises, as it appears most aukwardly, and are returned with the addition of a new-lac'd bosom and a Clap, to your good old father, who looks at you with his mouth, while you spout French with your Man Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Let me kiss thee again for that, dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: And you, I imagine, are my young Master, whom your Mother durst not trust upon salt water, but left you to be your own Tutour at fourteen, to be very brisk and entreprenant, to endeavour to be debauch'd ere you have learnt the knack on't, to value your self upon a Clap before you can get it, and to make it the height of your ambition to get a Player for your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: (embracing Mel.) O dear young Bully, thou hast tickled him with a repertee i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You are one of those that applaud our Countrey Plays, where drums, and trumpets, and bloud, and wounds, are wit.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Again, my Boy? let me kiss thee most abundantly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You are an admirer of the dull French Poetry, which is so thin, that it is the very Leaf-gold of Wit, the very Wafers and whip'd Cream of sense, for which a man opens his mouth and gapes, to swallow nothing: and to be an admirer of such profound dulness, one must be endow'd with a great perfection of impudence and ignorance.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Let me embrace thee most vehemently.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'll sacrifice my life for French Poetry. Advancing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'll die upon the spot for our Countrey Wit..

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: (to Melantha.) Hold, hold, young Mars: Palamede, draw back your Hero.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: 'Tis time; I shall be drawn in for a Second else at the wrong weapon.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O that I were a man for thy sake!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You'll be a man as soon as I shall.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Sir, the King has instant business with you.
I saw the Guard drawn up by your Lieutenant
Before the Palace-gate, ready to march.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.l: 'Tis somewhat sodain; say that I am coming
Now, Palamede, what think you of this sport?
This is some suddain tumult: will you along?

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will go; but the devil take me if ever I was less in humour. Why, the pox, could they not have staid their tumult till to morrow? then I had done my business, and been ready for 'em. Truth is, I had a little transitory crime to have committed first; and I am the worst man in the world at repenting, till a sin be throughly done: but what shall we do with the two Boys?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Let them take a lodging in the house till the business be over.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What, lie with a Boy? for my part, I own it, I cannot endure to lie with a Boy.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.p: The more's my sorrow, I cannot accommodate you with a better bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let me die, if I enter into a pair of sheets with him that hates the French.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pish, take no care for us, but leave us in the streets; I warrant you, as late as it is, I'll find my lodging as well as any drunken Bully of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: I'll fight in meer revenge, and wreak my passion Aside. On all that spoil this hopeful assignation.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.l: I'm sure we fight in a good quarrel:
Rogues may pretend Religion, and the Laws;
But a kind Mistris is the Good old Cause. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: You tell me wonders; that Leonidas
Is Prince Theagenes, the late King's Son.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: It seem'd as strange to him, as now to you,
Before I had convinc'd him; But, besides
His great resemblance to the King his Father,
The Queen his Mother lives, secur'd by me
In a Religious House; to whom each year
I brought the news of his increasing virtues.
My last long absence from you both, was caus'd
By wounds which, in my journey, I receiv'd,
When set upon by thieves; I lost those Jewels
And Letters, which your dying Mother left.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: The same he means, which, since, brought to the King,
Made him first know he had a Child alive:
'Twas then my care of Prince Leonidas
Caus'd me to say he was th'Usurpers Son;
Till, after forc'd by your apparent danger,
I made the true discovery of your birth,
And once more hid my Prince's.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hermogenes, and Eubulus, retire;
Those of our party, whom I left without,
Expect your aid and counsel. Exeunt ambo.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I should, Leonidas, congratulate
This happy change of your exalted fate;
But, as my joy, so you my wonder move;
Your looks have more of Business, then of Love:
And your last words some great design did show.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I frame not any to be hid from you.
You, in my love, all my designs may see;
But what have love and you design'd for me?
Fortune, once more, has set the ballance right
First, equall'd us, in lowness; then, in height.
Both of us have so long, like Gamesters, thrown,
Till Fate comes round, and gives to each his own.
As Fate is equal, so may Love appear:
Tell me, at least, what I must hope, or fear.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: After so many proofs, how can you call
My love in doubt? Fear nothing; and hope, all.
Think what a Prince, with honour, may receive,
Or I may give without a Parents leave.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You give, and then restrain the grace you show;
As ostentatious Priests, when Souls they wooe,
Promise their Heav'n to all, but grant to few.
But do for me, what I have dar'd for you.
I did no argument from duty bring:
Duty's a Name; and Love's a Real thing.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Man's love may, like wild torrents, over-flow;
Woman's as deep, but in its banks must go.
My love is mine; and that I can impart;
But cannot give my person, with my heart.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Your love is then no gift:
For when the person it does not convey,
'Tis to give Gold, and not to give the Key.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Then ask my Father.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — He detains my Throne:
Who holds back mine, will hardly give his own.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: What then remains?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — That I must have recourse
To Arms; and take my Love and Crown, by force.
Hermogenes is forming the design;
And with him, all the brave and loyal joyn.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: And is it thus you court Palmyra's bed?
Can she the murd'rer of her Parent wed?
Desist from force: so much you well may give
To Love, and Me, to let my Father live.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Each act of mine my love to you has shown;
But you, who tax my want of it, have none.
You bid me part with you, and let him live;
But they should nothing ask, who nothing give.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I give what vertue and what duty can,
In vowing ne'r to wed another man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You will be forc'd to be Argaleon's wife.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I'll keep my promise, though I lose my life.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Then you lose Love, for which we both contend;
For Life is but the means, but Love's the end.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Our Souls shall love hereafter.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — I much fear,
That Soul which could deny the Body here,
To taste of love, would be a niggard there.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Then 'tis past hope: our cruel fate, I see,
Will make a sad divorce 'twixt you and me.
For, if you force employ, by Heav'n I swear,
And all bless'd Beings,—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Your rash Oath forbear.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I never—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: — Hold once more. But, yet, as he
Who scapes a dang'rous leap, looks back to see;
So I desire, now I am past my fear,
To know what was that Oath you meant to swear.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: I meant that if you hazarded your life,
Or sought my Fathers, ne'r to be your Wife.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: See now, Palmyra, how unkind you prove!
Could you, with so much ease, forswear my love?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: You force me with your ruinous design.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Your Father's life is more your care, then Mine.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: You wrong me: 'tis not; though it ought to be;
You are my Care, heav'n knows, as well as he.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If now the execution I delay,
My Honour, and my Subjects, I betray.
All is prepar'd for the just enterprize;
And the whole City will to morrow rise.
The Leaders of the party are within,
And Eubulus has sworn that he will bring,
To head their Arms, the person of their King.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: In telling this, you make me guilty too;
I therefore must discover what I know:
What Honour bids you do, Nature bids me prevent;
But kill me first, and then pursue your black intent.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Palmyra, no; you shall not need to die;
Yet I'll not trust so strict a piety.
Within there.
— Eubulus, a Guard prepare;
Here, I commit this pris'ner to your care.

div.stage: Kisses Palmyra 's hand; then gives it to Eubulus,

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Leonidas, I never thought these bands
Could e'r be giv'n me by a Lover's hands.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Palmyra, thus your Judge himself arraigns; kneeling.
He who impos'd these bonds, still wears your chains:
When you to Love or Duty false must be,
Or to your Father guilty, or to me,
These chains, alone, remain to set you free.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: (within) Secure these, first; then search the inner room.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: From whence do these tumultuous clamours come?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: We are betray'd; and there remains alone
This comfort, that your person is not known.

div.stage: Enter the King, Argaleon, Rhodophil, Palamede, Guards; some like Citizens as prisoners.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: What mean this midnight-consultations here,
Where I, like an unsummon'd guest, appear?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir—

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: — There needs no excuse; 'tis understood;
You were all watching for your Prince's good.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: My reverend City-friends, you are well met!
On what great work were your grave wisdoms set?
Which of my actions were you scanning here?
What French invasion have you found to fear?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: They are my friends; and come, Sir, with intent
To take their leaves before my banishment.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Your exile, in both sexes friends can find:
I see the Ladies, like the men, are kind. Seeing Palmyra.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Alas, I came but— kneeling.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: — Adde not to your crime
A lie: I'll hear you speak some other time.
How? Eubulus! nor time, nor thy disguise,
Can keep thee, undiscover'd, from my eyes.
A Guard there; seize 'em all.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Yield, Sir; what use of valour can be shown?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: One, and unarm'd, against a multitude!
O for a sword!
sp.stage: He reaches at one of the Guards Halberds, and is seiz'd behind.
sp.l: — I w'not lose my breath
In fruitless pray'rs; but beg a speedy death.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: O spare Leonidas, and punish me.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Mean Girl, thou want'st an Advocate for thee.
Now the mysterious knot will be unty'd;
Whether the young King lives, or where he dy'd:
To morrows dawn shall the dark riddle clear;
Crown all my joys; and dissipate my fear. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Palamede, Straton. Palamede with a Letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: THis evening, say'st thou? will they both be here?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Yes Sir; both my old Master, and your Mistris's Father: the old Gentlemen ride hard this journey; they say, it shall be the last time they will see the Town; and both of 'em are so pleas'd with this marriage, which they have concluded for you, that I am afraid they will live some years longer to trouble you, with the joy of it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But this is such an unreasonable thing, to impose upon me to be marri'd to morrow; 'tis hurrying a man to execution, without giving him time to say his pray'rs.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Yet, if I might advise you, Sir, you should not delay it: for your younger Brother comes up with 'em, and is got already into their favours. He has gain'd much upon my old Master, by finding fault with Inn-keepers Bills, and by starving us, and our Horses, to show his frugality; and he is very well with your Mistris's Father, by giving him Receipts for the Splene, Gout, and Scurvy, and other infirmities of old age.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p:
I'll rout him, and his Countrey education: Pox on him,
I remember him before I travell'd, he had nothing in him but meer Jocky; us'd to talk loud, and make matches, and was all for the crack of the field: sense and wit were as much banish'd from his discourse, as they are when the Court goes out of Town to a Horse-race. Go now and provide your Master's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: I go, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: It vexes me to the heart, to leave all my designs with Doralice unfinish'd; to have flown her so often to a mark, and still to be bob'd at retrieve: if I had but once enjoy'd her, though I could not have satisfi'd my stomach, with the feast, at least I should have relish'd my mouth a little; but now—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you are happily met; I was coming to find you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: From your Lady, I hope.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Partly from her; but more especially from my self: she has just now receiv'd a Letter from her Fathet, with an absolute command to dispose her self to marry you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: And she takes it to the death?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Quite contrary: the Letter could never have come in a more lucky minute; for it found her in an ill humour with a Rival of yours, that shall be nameless, about the pronunciation of a French word.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Count Rhodophil; never disguise it, I know the Amour: but I hope you took the occasion to strike in for me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: It was my good fortune to do you some small service in it; for your sake I discommended him all over: cloaths, person, humour, behaviour, every thing; and to sum up all, told her, It was impossible to find a marri'd man that was otherwise; for they were all so mortifi'd at home with their wives ill humours, that they could never recover themselves to be company abroad.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Most divinely urg'd!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Then I took occasion to commend your good qualities: as, the sweetness of your humour, the comeliness of your
person, your good Meene, your valour; but, above all, your liberality.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: I vow to Gad I had like to have forgot that good quality in my self, if thou had'st not remember'd me on't: here are five Pieces for thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Lord, you have the softest hand, Sir! it would do a woman good to touch it: Count Rhodophil's is not half so soft; for I remember I felt it once, when he gave me ten Pieces for my New-years gift.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: O, I understand you, Madam; you shall find my hand as soft again as Count Rhodophil's: there are twenty Pieces for you. The former was but a Retaining Fee; now I hope you'l plead for me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your own merits speak enough. Be sure onely to ply her with French words, and I'll warrant you'll do your business. Here are a list of her phrases for this day: use 'em to her upon all occasions, and foil her at her own weapon; for she's like one of the old Amazons, she'l never marry, except it be the man who has first conquer'd her.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: I'll be sure to follow your advice: but you'll forget to further my design.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What, do you think I'll be ungrateful?— But, however, if you distrust my memory, put some token on my finger to remember it by: that Diamond there would do admirably.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: There 'tis; and I ask your pardon heartily for calling your memory into question: I assure you I'll trust it another time, without putting you to the trouble of another token.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Madam, this way the prisoners are to pass;
Here you may see Leonidas.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Then here I'll stay, and follow him to death.

sp.speaker: Mela.
sp.p: O, here's her Highness! Now is my time to introduce my self, and to make my court to her, in my new French phrases. Stay let me read my catalogue— suitte, figure, chagrin, naivete, and let me die for the Parenthesis of all.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: (aside) Do, persecute her; and I'll persecute thee as fast in thy own dialect.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Madam the Princess! let me die, but this is a most horrid spectacle, to see a person who makes so grand a figure in the Court, without the Suitte of a Princess, and entertaining your Chagrin all alone; (Naivete should have been there, but the disobedient word would not come in.)

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: What is she, Artemis?

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: An impertinent Lady, Madam; very ambitious of being known to your Highness.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: (to Melantha) Let me die. Madam, if I have not waited you here these two long hours, without so much as the Suitte of a single Servant to attend me; entertaining my self with my own Chagrin, till I had the honour to see your Ladiship, who are a person that makes so considerable a figure in the Court.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Truce with your douceurs, good servant; you see I am addressing to the Princess; pray do not embarrass me— embarrass me! what a delicious French word do you make me lose upon you too!

(To the Princess) Your Highness, Madam, will please to pardon the Beveue which I made, in not sooner finding you out to be a Princess: but let me die if this Eclaircissement which is made this day of your quality, does not ravish me; and give me leave to tell you—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But first give me leave to tell you, Madam, that I have so great a tender for your person, and such a panchant to do you service, that—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What, must I still be troubled with your Sottises? (There's another word lost, that I meant for the Princess, with a mischief to you) But your Highness, Madam—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But your Ladiship, Madam—

div.stage: Enter Leonidas guarded, and led over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Out upon him, how he looks, Madam! now he's found no Prince, he is the strangest figure of a man; how could I make that Coup d' etourdy to think him one?

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Away, impertinent— My dear Leonidas!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My dear Palmyra!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Death shall never part us;
My Destiny is yours. He is led off; she follows.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Impertinent! Oh I am the most unfortunate person this day breathing: that the Princess should thus rompre en visiere, without occasion. Let me die but I 'll follow her to death, till I make my peace.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: (holding her) And let me die, but I'll follow you to the Infernals till you pity me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (turning towards him angrily) Ay, 'tis long of you that this Malheur is fall'n upon me; your impertinence has put me out of the good graces of the Princess, and all that, which has ruin'd me and all that, and therefore let me die but I'll be reveng'd, and all that.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Façon, façon, you must and shall love me, and all that; for my old man is coming up, and all that; and I am desesperé au dernier, and will not be disinherited, and all that.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: How durst you interrupt me so mal a propos, when you knew I was addressing to the Princess?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But why would you address your self so much a contre-temps then?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ah mal peste!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Ah I'enrage!

p.hi: Radoucissez vous, de grace, Madame; vous êtes bien en colere pour pen de chose. Vous n' entendez pas la raillerie gallante.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ad ' autres, ad' autres: he mocks himself of me, he abuses me: ah me unfortunate! cries!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You mistake him, Madam, he does but accommodate his phrase to your refin'd language. Ah, qu'il est un Cavalier accomply! pursue your point, Sir— To him.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Ah qu'il fait beau dans ces boccages; Singing.
Ah que le ciel donne un beau jour!
There I was with you, with a minouét.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let me die now, but this singing is fine, and extremely French in him: Laughs. But then, that he should use my own words, as it were in contempt of me, I cannot bear it. Crying.

p.hi: Ces beaux sejours, ces doux ramages—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Ces beaux Sejours, ces doux ramages, Singing after him. Ces beaux sejours, nous invitent a l'amour! Let me die but he sings en Cavalier, and so humours the Cadence. Laughing.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Voy, ma Clymene, voy soubs ce chesne, Singing again. S'entrebaiser ces oiseaux amoreux! Let me die now, but that was fine. Ah, now, for three or four brisk Frenchmen, to be put into Masquing habits, and to sing it on a Theatre, how witty it would be! and then to dance helter skelter to a Chanson a boire: toute la terre, toute la terre est a moy! what's matter though it were made, and sung, two or three years ago in Cabarets, how it would attract the admiration, especially of every one that's an eveille!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well; I begin to have a tender for you; but yet, upon condition, that— when we are marri'd, you—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You must drown her voice: if she makes her French conditions, you are a slave for ever.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: First, will you engage— that

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, &c. Louder.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Will you hear the conditions?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: No; I will hear no conditions! I am resolv'd to win you en Francois: to be very aiery, with abundance of noise, and no sense: Fa, la, la, la, &c.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hold, hold: I am vanquish'd with your gayeté d' esprit. I am yours, and will be yours, sans nulle reserve, ny condition: and let me die, if I do not think my self the happiest Nymph in Sicily— My dear French Dear, stay but a minuite, till I raccommode my self with the Princess; and then I am yours, jusq' a la mort.
Allons done— Exeunt Mel. Philot.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p:
(Solus, fanning himself with his hat) I never thought before
that wooing was so laborious an exercise; if she were worth a million, I have deserv'd her; and now, me-thinks too, with taking all this pains for her, I begin to like her. 'Tis so; I have known many, who never car'd for Hare nor Partridge, but those they caught themselves would eat heartily: the pains, and the story a man tells of the taking of 'em, makes the meat go down more pleasantly. Besides, last night I had a sweet dream of her, and, Gad, she I have once dream'd of, I am stark mad till I enjoy her, let her be never so ugly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Who's that you are so mad to enjoy, Palamede?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: You may easily imagine that, sweet Doralice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: More easily then you think I can: I met just now with a certain man, who came to you with Letters, from a certain old Gentleman, yclipped your father; whereby I am given to understand, that to morrow you are to take an Oath in the Church to be grave henceforward, to go ill-dress'd and slovenly, to get heirs for your estate, and to dandle 'em for your diversion; and, in short, that Love and Courtship are to be no more.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Now have I so much shame to be thus apprehended in the manner, that I can neither speak nor look upon you; I have abundance of grace in me, that I find: But if you have any spark of true friendship in you, retire a little with me to the next room, that has a couch or bed in't, and bestow your charity upon a poor dying man: a little comfort from a Mistris, before a man is going to give himself in Marriage, is as good as a lusty dose of Strong-water to a dying Malefactour; it takes away the sense of hell, and hanging from him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, good Palamede, I must not be so injurious to your Bride: 'tis ill drawing from the Bank to day, when all your ready money is payable to morrow.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: A Wife is onely to have the ripe fruit, that falls of it self; but a wise man will always preserve a shaking for a Mistris.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But a Wife for the first quarter is a Mistris.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But when the second comes.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: When it does come, you are so given to variety, that you would make a Wife of me in another quarter.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: No, never, except I were married to you: marri'd people can never oblige one another; for all they do is duty, and consequently there can be no thanks: but love is more frank and generous then he is honest; he's a liberal giver, but a cursed pay-master.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I declare I will have no Gallant; but, if I would, he should never be a marri'd man; a marri'd man is but a Mistris's half-servant, as a Clergy-man is but the King's half-subject: for a man to come to me that smells o' th' Wife! 's life, I wou'd as soon wear her old Gown after her, as her Husband.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Yet 'tis a kind of fashion to wear a Princess cast shoes, you see the Countrey Ladies buy 'em to be fine in them.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, a Princess shoes may be worn after her, because they keep their fashion, by being so very little us'd; but generally a marri'd man is the creature of the world the most out of fashion; his behaviour is dumpish, his discourse his wife and family, his habit so much neglected, it looks as if that were marri'd too; his Hat is marri'd, his Perruke is marri'd, his Breeches are marri'd, and if we could look within his Breeches, we should find him marri'd there too.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Am I then to be discarded for ever? pray do but mark how terrible that word sounds; For ever! it has a very damn'd sound, Doralice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, for ever! it sounds as hellishly to me, as it can do to you, but there's no help for't.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Yet if we had but once enjoy'd one another; but then once onely, is worse then not at all: it leaves a man with such a lingring after it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For ought I know 'tis better that we have not; we might upon trial have lik'd each other less, as many a man and woman, that have lov'd as desperately as we, and yet when they came to possession, have sigh'd, and cri'd to themselves, Is this all?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p:
That is onely, if the Servant were not found a man of this world; but if, upon trial, we had not lik'd each other, we
had certainly left loving; and faith, that's the greater happiness of the two.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis better as 'tis; we have drawn off already as much of our Love as would run clear; after possessing, the rest is but jealousies, and disquiets, and quarrelling, and piecing.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Nay, after one great quarrel, there's never any sound piecing; the love is apt to break in the same place again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I declare I would never renew a love; that's like him who trims an old Coach for ten years together, he might buy a new one better cheap.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I am convinc'd, that 'tis best for us not to have enjoy'd; but Gad, the strongest reason is, because I cann't help it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The onely way to keep us new to one another, is never to enjoy, as they keep grapes by hanging 'em upon a line, they must touch nothing if you would preserve 'em fresh.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: But then they wither, and grow dry in the very keeping; however I shall have a warmth for you, and an eagerness, every time I see you; and if I chance to out-live Melantha—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And if I chance to out-live Rhodophil—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Well, I'll cherish my body as much as I can upon that hope. 'Tis true, I would not directly murder the wife of my bosome; but to kill her civilly, by the way of kindness, I'll put as fair as another man: I'll begin to morrow night, and be very wrathful with her, that's resolv'd on.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, Palamede, here's my hand, I'll venture to be your second Wife, for all your threatnings.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: In the mean time I'll watch you hourly, as I would the ripeness of a Melon, and I hope you'll give me leave now and then to look on you, and to see if you are not ready to be cut yet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, no, that must not be, Palamede, for fear the Gardener should come and catch you taking up the glass.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: (Aside) Billing so sweetly! now I am confirm'd in my suspicions; I must put an end to this, ere it go further. Aside.
(To Doralice) Cry you mercy, Spouse; I fear I have interrupted your recreations.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What recreations?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Nay, no excuses, good Spouse; I saw fair hand convey'd to lip, and prest, as though you had been squeezing soft wax together for an Indenture. Palamede, you and I must clear this reckoning; why would you have seduc'd my wife?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Why would you have debauch'd my Mistris?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: What do you think of that civil couple, that play'd at a Game call'd, Hide and Seek, last evening, in the Grotto?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: What do you think of that innocent pair, who made it their pretence to seek for others, but came, indeed, to hide themselves there?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: All things consider'd, I begin vehemently to suspect, that the young Gentleman I found in your company last night, was a certain youth of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: And I have an odd imagination, that you could never have suspected my small Gallant, if your little villanous Frenchman had not been a false Brother.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Farther Arguments are needless; Draw off; I shall speak to you now by the way of Bilbo.

div.stage: Claps his hand to his sword.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: And I shall answer you by the way of Danger-field.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hold, hold; are not you two a couple of mad fighting fools, to cut one another's throats for nothing?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: How for nothing? he courts the woman I must marry.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: And he courts you whom I have marri'd.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But you can neither of you be jealous of what you love not.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Faith I am jealous, and that makes me partly suspect that I love you better then I thought.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pish! a meer jealousie of honour.

sp.speaker: Rho
sp.p: Gad I am afraid there's something else in't; for Palamede has wit and if he loves you, there's something more in ye then I have found: some rich Mine, for ought I know, that I have not yetdiscovered.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p:
'S life, what's this? here's an argument for me to love
Melantha; for he has lov'd her, and he has wit too, and, for ought I know, there may be a Mine: but, if there be, I am resolv'd I'll dig for 't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: (to Rhod.) Then I have found my account in raising your jealousie: O! 'tis the most delicate sharp sawce to a cloy'd stomach; it will give you a new edge, Rhodophil.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: And a new point too, Doralice, if I could be sure thou art honest.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If you are wise, believe me for your own sake: Love and Religion have but one thing to trust to; that's a good sound faith. Consider, if I have play'd false, you can never find it out by any experiment you can make upon me.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: No? Why, suppose I had a delicate screw'd Gun, if I left her clean, and found her foul, I should discover, to my cost, she had been shot in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But if you left her clean, and found her onely rusty, you would discover, to your shame, she was onely so for want of shooting.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Rhodophil, you know me too well, to imagine I speak for fear; and therefore in consideration of our past friendship, I will tell you, and bind it by all things holy, that Doralice is innocent.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Friend, I will believe you, and vow the same for your Melantha; but the devil on't is, how we shall keep 'em so.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: What dost think of a blessed community betwixt us four, for the solace of the women, and relief of the men? Methinks it would be a pleasant kind of life: Wife and Husband for the standing Dish and Mistris and Gallant for the Desert.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: But suppose the Wife and the Mistris should both long for the standing Dish, how should they be satisfi'd together?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: In such a case they must draw lots: and yet that would not do neither; for they would both be wishing for the longest out?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Then I think, Palamede, we had as good make a firm League, not to invade each others propriety.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Content, say I. From henceforth let all acts of hostility cease betwixt us; and that in the usual form of Treaties, as well by Sea as by Land, and in all Fresh waters.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I will adde but one Proviso, That who ever breaks the League, either by war abroad, or by neglect at home, both the Women shall revenge themselves, by the help of the other party.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: That's but reasonable. Come away, Doralice; I have a great temptation to be sealing Articles in private.

sp.speaker: Palam.
sp.l: Hast thou so? Claps him on the shoulder.
Fall on, Machduss,
And curst be he that first cries, Hold, enough.

div.stage: Enter Polydamas, Palmyra, Artemis, Argaleon: after them, Eubulus, and Hermogenes, guarded.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Sir, on my knees I beg you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Away, I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: For my dead Mother's sake; you say you lov'd her,
And tell me I resemble her. Thus she
Had begg'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: — And thus had I deny'd her.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: You must be merciful.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: — You must be constant.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Go, bear 'em to the torture; you have boasted
You have a King to head you: I would know
To whom I must resign.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: — This is our recompence
For serving thy dead Queen.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: — And education
Of thy daughter.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: You are too modest, in not naming all
His obligations to you: why did you
Omit his Son, the Prince Leonidas?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That Imposture
I had forgot; their tortures shall be doubled.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You please me, I shall die the sooner.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: No; could I live an age, and still be rack'd,
I still would keep the secret.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Oh whither do you hurry innocence!
If you have any justice, spare their lives;
Or if I cannot make you just, at least
I'll teach you to more purpose to be cruel.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Alas, what does he seek!

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Make me the object of your hate and vengeance!
Are these decrepid bodies worn to ruine,
Just ready, of themselves, to fall asunder,
And to let drop the soul,
Are these fit subjects for a Rack, and Tortures?
Where would you fasten any hold upon 'em?
Place pains on me; united fix 'em here;
I have both youth, and strength, and soul to bear 'em:
And if they merit death, then I much more;
Since 'tis for me they suffer.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: — Heav'n forbid
We should redeem our pains, or worthless lives,
By our exposing yours.

sp.speaker: Eub.
sp.l: Away with us: Farewell, Sir.
I onely suffer in my fears for you.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: So much concern'd for him? then my Aside
Suspicion's true.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Hear yet my last request, for poor Leonidas;
Or take my life with his.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Rest satisfi'd; Leonidas is he. To the King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I am amaz'd: what must be done?

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Command his execution instantly;
Give him not leisure to discover it;
He may corrupt the Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hence with that Traitour; bear him to his death:
Haste there, and see my will perform'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay, then I'll die like him the Gods have made me.
Hold, Gentlemen; I am—

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: Thou art a Traitor; 'tis not fit to hear thee.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I say I am the— Getting loose a little.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: So; gag him, and lead him off.

div.stage: Leonidas, Hermogenes, Eubulus, led off. Polydamas and Argaleon follow.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Duty and Love, by turns possess my soul,
And struggle for a fatal victory:
I will discover he's the King; Ah, no:
That will perhaps save him;
But then I am guilty of a father's ruine.
What shall I do or not do? either way
I must destroy a Parent, or a Lover.
Break heart; for that's the least of ills to me,
And Death the onely cure. Swoons.

sp.speaker: Arte.
sp.l: Help, help the Princess.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: Bear her gently hence, where she may
Have more succour. She is born off, Arte. follows her.

div.stage: Shouts within, and clashing of swords.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: Oh, Gentlemen, if you have loyalty,
Or courage, show it now: Leonidas
Broke on the sudden from his Guards, and snatching
A sword from one, his back against the Scaffold,
Bravely defends himself; and owns aloud
He is our long lost King, found for this moment;
But, if your valours help not, lost for ever.
Two of his Guards, mov'd by the sense of virtue,
Are turn'd for him, and there they stand at Bay
Against an host of foes.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: — Madam, no more;
We lose time: my command, or my example,
May move the Soldiers to the better cause.
You'll second me? To Pal.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Or die with you: no Subject e'r can meet
A nobler fate, then at his Sovereign's feet. Exeunt.

div.stage: Clashing of swords within, and shouts.
Enter Leonidas, Rhodophil, Palamede, Eubulus, Hermogenes, and their party, victorious. Polydamas and Argaleon, disarm'd.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That I survive the dangers of this day,
Next to the Gods, brave friends, be yours the honour.
And let Heav'n witness for me, that my joy
Is not more great for this my right restor'd,
Than 'tis, that I have power to recompence
Your Loyalty and Valour. Let mean Princes
Of abject souls, fear to reward great actions;
I mean to show,
That whatsoe'r subjects, like you, dare merit,
