A King, like me, dares give—

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.l: You make us blush, we have deserv'd so little.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And yet instruct us how to merit more.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: And as I would be just in my rewards,
So should I in my punishments; these two,
This the Usurper of my Crown, the other
Of my Palmyra's love, deserve that death
Which both design'd for me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: — And we expect it.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: I have too long been happy to live wretched.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And I too long have govern'd, to desire
A life without an Empire.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You are Palmyra's father; and as such,
Though not a King, shall have obedience paid
From him who is one. Father, in that name,
All injuries forgot, and duty own'd. Embraces him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O, had I known you could have been this King,
Thus God-like, great and good, I should have wish'd
T' have been dethron'd before. 'Tis now I live,
And more then Reign; now all my joys flow pure,
Unmix'd with cares, and undisturb'd by conscience.

div.stage: Enter Palmyra, Amalthea, Artemis, Doralice, and Melantha.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: See, my Palmyra comes! the frighted bloud
Scarce yet recall'd to her pale cheeks,
Like the first streaks of light broke loose from darkness,
And dawning into blushes.— Sir, you said, To Polyda.
Your joys were full; Oh, would you make mine so!
I am but half-restor'd without this blessing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The Gods, and my Palmyra, make you happy,
As you make me. Gives her hand to Leonidas.

sp.speaker: Palmy.
sp.l: — Now all my prayers are heard:
I may be dutiful, and yet may love.
Virtue, and patience, have at length unravell'd
The knots which Fortune ty'd.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Let me die, but I'll congratulate his
Majesty: how admirably well his Royalty
Becomes him! Becomes! that is luy sied, but our damn'd Language expresses nothing.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: How? does it become him already? 'twas but just now you said, he was such a figure of a man.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: True, my dear, when he was a private man he was a figure; but since he is a King, methinks he has assum'd another figure: he looks so grand, and so August.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Stay, stay; I'll present you when it is more convenient. I find I must get her a place at Court; and when she is once there, she can be no longer ridiculous; for she is young enough, and pretty enough, and fool enough, and French enough, to bring up a fashion there to be affected.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: (to Rhodophil) Did she then lead you to this brave attempt?
(To Amalthea) To you, fair Amalthea, what I am,
And what all these, from me, we joyntly owe:
First, therefore, to your great desert, we give
Your Brother's life; but keep him under guard,
Till our new power be setled. What more grace
He may receive, shall from his future carriage
Be given, as he deserves.

sp.speaker: Arga.
sp.l: I neither now desire, nor will deserve it;
My loss is such as cannot be repair'd,
And to the wretched, life can be no mercy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Then be a prisoner always: thy ill fate,
And pride will have it so: but since, in this, I cannot,
Instruct me, generous Amalthea, how
A King may serve you.

sp.speaker: Amal.
sp.l: — I have all I hope,
And all I now must wish; I see you happy.
Those hours I have to live, which Heav'n in pity
Will make but few, I vow to spend with Vestals:
The greatest part, in pray'rs for you; the rest
In mourning my unworthiness.
Press me not farther to explain my self;
'Twill not become me, and may cause your trouble.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Too well I understand her secret grief, Aside.
But dare not seem to know it.— Come To Palmyra. my fairest,
Beyond my Crown, I have one joy in store;
To give that Crown to her whom I adore.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: THus have my Spouse and I inform'd the Nation,
And led you all the way to Reformation.
Not with dull Morals, gravely writ, like those,
Which men of easie Phlegme, with care compose.
Your Poet's of stiff words, and limber sense,
Born on the confines of indifference.
But by examples drawn, I dare to say,
From most of you, who hear, and see the Play.
There are more Rhodophils in this Theatre,
More Palamedes, and some few Wives, I fear.
But yet too far our Poet would not run,
Though 'twas well offer'd, there was nothing done.
He would not quite the Woman's frailty bare,
But stript 'em to the waste, and left 'em there.
And the men's faults are less severely shown,
For he considers that himself is one.
Some stabbing Wits, to bloudy Satyr bent,
Would treat both Sexes with less complement:
Would lay the Scene at home, of Husbands tell,
For Wenches, taking up their Wives i' th' Mell,
And a brisk bout which each of them did want,
Made by mistake of Mistris and Gallant.
Our modest Authour, thought it was enough
To out you off a Sample of the stuff:
He spar'd my shame, which you, I'm sure, would not,
For you were all for driving on the Plot:
You sigh'd when I came in to break the sport,
And set your teeth when each design fell short.
To Wives, and Servants all good wishes lend,
But the poor Cuckold seldom finds a friend.
Since therefore Court and Town will take no pity,
I humbly cast my self upon the City.
